text:
The documentation on Keepalive doesn't say if incoming requests preempt
Keepalives or not.

If incoming requests will have to wait for Keepalives to finish, that is a
separate issue and I'll log a bug on that.
creator: ftlofaro@yahoo.com

text:
What documentation?  The description of the directive just tells you that it
enables an HTTP feature.  It's not the role of the Apache documentation to
reproduce RFC2616.
creator: nick@webthing.com

text:
If there are 150 of 150 Apache processes running and they are all in 'K' state
and a new request does it block waiting on a 'K' process to end (which is dumb)
or does it do the right thing and preempt one of the keepalives and run on the
then freed child?

The docs don't say.
creator: ftlofaro@yahoo.com

text:
Did you read the performance tuning docs?  If you are affected by that kind of
limit, you're using the wrong MPM.

I'll leave this open, because you do have a point: the KeepAliveTimeout
documentation looks as if it hasn't been updated since Apache 1.x.  What it
needs is a link to an article explaining how choice of MPM affects this.
(This seems to imply setting it to ASSIGNED, as bugzilla isn't offering the
option to revert to NEW).
creator: nick@webthing.com

text:
I don't really see anything specific to be fixed in the docs here. The KeepAlive
docs certainly aren't the place to start discussing general performance tuning
issues.
